Award.AwardTitle: EAGER; Exploratory Research for a Mass Flow Apparatus Facility
Award.AbstractNarration:
1464308
Sonder

This EAGER grant will suport exploration of experimental, design, and management concepts for a potential user facility to allow for unprecedented in scale (10-100 m) experimental simulation of terrestrial mass flows (5-10 t of material). An envisioned mass flow apparatus (MFA) on the size scale and with capabilities hoped for (e.g., multiple material release modalities, variable ramp inclination and surface topography as well as a range of ramp embedded sensing modalities) was a concept recommendation of a recent NSF supported workshop that engaged an international community of volcanologists. As such the PIs will first target the considerations necessary to simulate pyroclastic flows though the MFA would be suitable for experimental study of landslides. The MFA would allow for study of mixed phase mass flows where initial boundary conditions are controlled and the resultant deposits would be studied to help improve numerical models of the behavior of mass flows and to ultimately use those models to help mitigate mass flow hazards. Topics to be further studied using EAGER support include: 1) the sourcing, handling, delivery and preparation of suitable starting materials for target simulations; 2) design of the variable inclination ramp, provision for modification of surface morphology and integration of specific sensing modalities and engineering consideration of the ramps structural design and response to dynamic loads of the mass scales envisioned; 3) consideration of management issues (e.g., time and costs of experiment set up and clean up, scheduling, cost recovery estimates for target experiment types and longer term usage considerations ? maintenance.) The envisioned MFA offers a potentially transformative experimental resource for study of hazardous mass flows under controlled settings at unprecedented scales and with sensing capabilities that cannot be applied in situ under natural conditions. This EAGER grant will support the additional exploratory considerations necessary to refine MFA design consideration and management concepts that could result in a tractable MFA that could support broad use by the geoscience community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated potentially critical points for the development of a 10–100 m size experimental facility aiming to investigate the physical characteristics of geologic mass flows, such as pyroclastic density currents, lahars and landslides. For this wide range of potential application a generic experimental setup was proposed which would provide the necessary experimental capabilities: a ramp structure with adaptable slope, and a variety of material discharge capabilities. The exploratory investigations focused on the delivery and handling practices of experimental base material, testing of sensors and the ramp structure, and the consideration of facility management aspects.

At the proposed scale one experimental run involves about 10 m3 of experimental base material. Availability and quality of representative material originating from pyroclastic density deposits was studied, and the geologic records were checked. Based on that several possible sources were identified that provide the volcanic ash/lapilli sized material in per truck or smaller units. They also provide basic material quality services, such as grain size range selection, and moisture content control.

 

For the sensor integration studies a 2 m x 2 m sized test ramp was constructed on which material was dropped to simulate typical dynamic loads. Vibrations were found to be significant, but managable. Depending on the sensor speed and sensitivity different damping techniques have to be used. For the test ramp a suitable damping configuration was found. For the Mass Flow Apparatus two main ramp design directions are proposed, each of which have positives and negatives

  1. A largely steel based design, that includes some vibration damping provisions, as proposed in the MRI projects. Advantages include a relatively flexible inclination angle, and possibly easy cleanup and accessibility. Negatives include some structural issues, and vibrations which depend on the dynamic loads imposed on the structure, and differ significantly based on the wide spread targeted applications.

  2. A design in which the main slope rests on a (artificial hill) slope. Positives here are low vibrations, which have high similarity to natural seismic signals. Negatives include less flexibility in the inclination angle, and a larger footprint, since several slopes likely would have to be constructed.

Experiments using the large scale mass flow apparatus should be structured into sessions of one or several experiment groups, which would then consist of several experimental runs. Taking into account the various pre- and post experimental activities, and experiment can happen about once per week. For each experiment group material will have to be acquired, which adds to the preparation time. 3 to 4 experiments per month are realistic.

 

For the volcanology community each run of such a facility would have to be considered a significant event, that should be observed by several, possibly competing, research groups. The possible benefit of the research community society would be significant.

 

The experimental setup became the base for a project funded by the Petrology & Geochemnistry Program aiming at a specific subset of a geologic mass flow problem (Valentine, Sonder, Bursik: "Impact of Collapsing Gas-particle Jets: The Initial Conditions for Pyroclastic Flows and Surges").
